metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Python - Access List Items
Access Items
List items are indexed and you can access them by referring to the index number:
content.html: List items are indexed and you can access them by referring to the index number:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist[1])

content.text: Note: The first item has index 0.
Negative Indexing
Negative indexing means start from the end
content.html: Negative indexing means start from the end

content.text: -1 refers to the last item, -2 refers to the second last item etc.
content.html: -1 refers to the last item, -2 refers to the second last item etc.

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist[-1])

content.text: Range of Indexes
You can specify a range of indexes by specifying where to start and where to end the range.
content.html: You can specify a range of indexes by specifying where to start and where to end the range.

content.text: When specifying a range, the return value will be a new list with the specified items.
content.html: When specifying a range, the return value will be a new list with the specified items.

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
print(thislist[2:5])

content.text: Note: The search will start at index 2 (included) and end at index 5 (not included).
content.html: Note: The search will start at index 2 (included) and end at index 5 (not included).

content.text: Remember that the first item has index 0.
content.html: Remember that the first item has index 0.

content.text: By leaving out the start value, the range will start at the first item:
content.html: By leaving out the start value, the range will start at the first item:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
print(thislist[:4])

content.text: By leaving out the end value, the range will go on to the end of the list:
content.html: By leaving out the end value, the range will go on to the end of the list:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
print(thislist[2:])

content.text: Range of Negative Indexes
Specify negative indexes if you want to start the search from the end of the list:
content.html: Specify negative indexes if you want to start the search from the end of the list:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango"]
print(thislist[-4:-1])

content.text: Check if Item Exists
To determine if a specified item is present in a list use the in keyword:
content.html: To determine if a specified item is present in a list use the in keyword:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
  if "apple" in thislist:  print("Yes, 'apple' is in the fruits list")

content.code:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
if "apple" in thislist:  print("Yes, 'apple' is in the fruits list")

syntax_highlighting.text:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
 if "apple" in thislist:  print("Yes, 'apple' is in the fruits list")

content.code_html:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
if "apple" in thislist:
  print("Yes, 'apple' is in the fruits list")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
  if "apple" in thislist:  print("Yes, 'apple' is in the fruits list")

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following syntax: mylist = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry'] print(mylist[-1])
content.html:
What will be the result of the following syntax:
mylist = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
print(mylist[-1])
